titleStmt.title: Joseph Shenneberger to James F. Robinson
CWG8832

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, James F. Robinson: Governor's Official Correspondence File, Petitions for Pardons, Remissions, and Respites, 1862-1863

body.p:
His Excellency
The Govr of Kentucky

The undersigned petitioner would most respectfully State, that at the present term of the Jefferson Circuit Court he was tried upon an indictment in Said Court charging him with the Commission of a Robbery upon one Mrs Elizabeth Newton, in Connexion with one Elisha Applegate, -- Now your petitioner would State (and the proof in the case shows it) that Applegate is an Entire Stranger to petitioner, form the proof there is no doubt but that Applegate did rob the house of Mrs Newton, and there is no doubt but that at the time Applegate Committed the offense that Some other person was seen near the house when the offense was Committed, the proof showed that that other person was not nearer the house than 34 yards, the offense was committed in the dead hour of the night and the only proof that connected me with the crime was that of a young Lady a Granddaughter of Mrs Newtons who said she looked out of the door & Saw me standing near the yard gate and recognized me, and that was the only proof against me, now your petitioner would most solemly avow in the presence of that God to whom he has to account in another world for all the deeds done in this life, that he knew nothing of the matter, and had nothing to do with or any Knowledge of the matter whatever, and that the young lady is Mistaken in my identity.
I have lived in Jefferson County Ky many years and during the whole time I have honestly tried to make a living for myself and family by hard labour, I have a wife & children, and I assure your Excellency that death would have been far preferable to me than that Such a charge should have been made against me, but all I can now hope is that your Excellency will Extend to me that mercy which I know I am Entitled to, that you will remit the finding of the Jury in my case and let me show the public by my acts that I am still an honest man, and as in duty bound I will Ever pray &c

Louisville May 13th 1863
Most Respectfully
Joseph Shenneberger

We the undersigned petitioners are acquainted with the above petitioner Joseph Shenneberger Know him to be a man of truth, believe his statements are true and cheerfully unite with him in asking your Excellency to grant him a pardon, believing as good citizens that Justice demands the Same

Mike Goss
Jakob Shangenbarker
Jacob Sheidel
Joseph Ross
Patrick Minihan
C. Rodes
W C Price
Tho W Gibson
Jeff Williams
Michael Snyder

I sign the within Petition upon the recommendation of the Jury

Wm W, Twyman

E R Seeler
F. Jack Comm Clk Jeff County Court

L A Wood
Jno Talbott Esarrow J. C.
Thomas Melvogue

H C Hoffman
O B Church Clek of Police
W R Hydes Marshal City of Louisville
Jos Clement Justice of the Peace Jeff Co Ky.
A. M. Gazlay

Since the Examining trial in the City Court of Louisville of the petitioner, many circumstances favorable to the accused have been developed, & the Jury having asked that he be pardoned, & knowing them to be prudent and Just men, I cheerfully unite in his prayer --

E. S. Craig W, G, Reasor City atto
Phil Toppert Jr. Clerk
Member of City Council
H SuKamp
Jos Waissel
BoB. J. Hamilton

Burtan Tarner Deputy Justice Jeff Co
The following is a copy of the vertict of the Jury, who tried and convicted Joseph Shoenberger (indicted with Elisha Applegate) at the May Term 1863 of the Jefferson Circuit Court, towit.

We of the Jury find the defendant Joseph Shoenberger, guilty as charged in the within Indictment, and say he shall be confined in the Jail and Penitentiary House of this Commonwealth for the term of Three years, but at the same time, as a body would earnestly and most respectfully recommend him to the clemancy of the Executive

John Gill, foreman
May 14th 1863 A copy
att Jas P Chambers clk

The undersigned members of the jury who tried Joseph Shoenberger respectfully but earnestly recommend him to executive clemency and pray that his sentence may be remitted by the Governor -- His previous character was excellent. The testimony was conflicting, and depended upon the recognition of the prisoner in the night time by a young girl ^of seventeen years old.^ at a distance of thirty five steps -- she being in thedoor way house and the prisoner out of doors which ^cause^ of to doubt whether the recognition was complete

John H Thomas
Tho. B. Overton
Joseph Griffith
John D. Atter
F O Smith
